Knowledge Point: As pointed out above, most of this chapter will be concerned with the order of constituents and the marking of S, A and O arguments.\footnote{\label{fn:379}See Footnote \ref{fn:109} on p.~\pageref{fn:109} on the terms S, A and O. In this grammar, any clause in which an O argument is either expressed or implied, is counted as transitive\is{Verb!transitive} (regardless other arguments); a clause without an expressed or implied O is considered intransitive (cf. (\ref{ex:3.84}–\ref{ex:3.86}) on p.~\pageref{ex:3.84})\is{Verb!intransitive}. Knowledge Point: However, the notion of agentivity as involving a volitional participant deliberately performing the action, may be too narrow. Knowledge Point: More generally, the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} is frequently omitted when the object is highly predictable. For example, ao ‘serve food’ in \REF{ex:8.41} is naturally used with food as object, and haka hū ‘to light, kindle’ in \REF{ex:8.42} has either a fire or an engine as direct object. With both verbs, the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} tends to be omitted:
Content 1: \gll I ao mai era \textbf{te} \textbf{kai} he \ꞌate māmoe. | \gls PFV serve_food hither DIST ART food PRED liver sheep | \glt ‘When the food was served, it was sheep liver.’
Content 2: \gll He haka hū \textbf{te} \textbf{ahi,} he tunu he kakai. | \gls NTR CAUS burn ART fire NTR cook NTR PL:eat | \glt ‘They kindled the fire, cooked and ate.’

Knowledge Point: This argument may not be as strong as it seems, though, as it is not certain that deletion in these clauses only operates on subjects. Patients (i.e. direct objects) are freely omitted in Rapa Nui, both in main clauses and in mo{}-clauses, without any evidence of passivisation\is{Passive}. See for example \REF{ex:8.49}, where the Agent is expressed as a possessor (as is usual in mo{}-clauses, \sectref{sec:11.5.1.2}), while in \REF{ex:8.50} the Agent is not expressed at all. In both cases the Patient is left unexpressed under coreferentiality\is{Referentiality} with a constituent of the matrix clause, even though there is no evidence that the Patient is subject of the mo{}-clause.

Knowledge Point: There are semantic/pragmatic clues, however. A possible indication is, whether or not the clause has an implied Agent. When the Agent is left out in active clauses, this is usually because it is already known; it is coreferential with a noun phrase in a previous clause. In \REF{ex:8.44} above, here repeated, the identity of the Agent is known, so we may presume that the sentence is active. Moreover, the Agent is topical\is{Topic, topicality}, therefore likely to be the subject. In other words, this example is an active clause with implied Agent:
Content 1: \gll He to\ꞌo mai, he haka \textbf{pā} \textbf{te} \textbf{kūpeŋa}. | \gls NTR take hither NTR CAUS double ART net | \glt ‘He took the net and folded it.’

Knowledge Point: Besides this semantic criterion, there are also syntactic clues for passivity. Cross-linguistically, there is a correlation between passive voice and perfect aspect\is{Aspect!perfect}.\footnote{\label{fn:415}See e.g. \citet[84]{Comrie1976}; \citet[382]{Foley2007}; \citet[340]{KeenanDryer2007}; \citet[219]{Dixon2012}. Cf. \citet{Milner1973}, who argues that the difference between suffixed and unsuffixed verbs in \ili{Samoan} (a distinction usually described as active versus passive) has to do with aspect, not voice.} The perfect aspect\is{Aspect!perfect} focuses on the state resulting from the action, rather than the action itself; similarly, the passive tends to focus on the result of the activity and its effect on the patient. As it happens, quite a few examples of the passive in Rapa Nui are in the perfect aspect\is{Aspect!perfect}, like \REF{ex:8.46}, \REF{ex:8.47} and \REF{ex:8.58} above.
Content 1: \gll Ko hiko \ꞌā tā\ꞌaku haraoa e Te Manu. | \gls PRF snatch CONT POSS.1SG.A bread AG Te Manu | \glt ‘My bread has been snatched by Te Manu.’
Content 2: \gll Ku ŋau \ꞌana Kirireva e te niuhi. | \gls PRF bite CONT Kirireva AG ART shark | \glt ‘Kirireva has been bitten by a shark.’
Content 3: \gll Hora iva ko tari \ꞌā \textbf{te} \textbf{taŋata} ki ruŋa ki te pahī. | \gls hour nine PRF transport CONT ART man to above to ART ship | \glt ‘At nine o’clock the people are transported aboard the ship.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, a syntactic indication for passivisation in \REF{ex:8.58} is the fact that the Patient does not have accusative marking. In general, the accusative marker is obligatory in VO-clauses with human Patient.

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:8.5.3}.1} The verb \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} ‘to be full’ has two possible argument structures: the subject either expresses the filled entity (the Container) as in \REF{ex:8.63}, or the filling entity (the Substance) as in \REF{ex:8.64}.\footnote{\label{fn:417}While this alternating argument structure is not uncommon for verbs meaning ‘full’ in Polynesian (Ross Clark, p.c.), in Rapa Nui it represents an independent development: \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} was borrowed from \ili{Tahitian}\is{Tahitian influence}, where the Container is always subject and the Substance is marked with the multifunctional preposition i.} When the Substance is subject, the Container may be expressed as a locative phrase (\textit{{\ꞌ}i rote vai} in \REF{ex:8.65}).

Content 2: \gll Ko \ꞌī \ꞌana te taŋata \ꞌi rote vai. | \gls PRF full CONT ART man at inside_the water | \glt ‘There were plenty of people in the water, the water was full of people.’

And the water will be full of bad things.’

Knowledge Point: In the examples in the previous section, the preposed constituent is subject or object of the clause. Rapa Nui also has a topic-comment construction, in which a topic noun phrase is followed by a complete clause providing information about this topic. The topic NP is left-dislocated\is{Dislocation!left}: it is not part of the following clause and does not necessarily have a semantic role in relation to the predicate of the clause. The topic may be coreferential to an argument of the verb (as in \REF{ex:8.78} below, where it is coreferential to the A of aŋa), but it is not a verb argument itself; the comment is a complete clause in its own right. Below are a few examples.
Content 1: \gll \obTe matu\ꞌa tane o Taparahi\,\cb\textsubscriptTOP \obte aŋa iŋa \ꞌi Mataveri.\,\cb\textsubscriptCOM | \gls {\db}ART parent male of Taparahi {\db}ART work NMLZ at Mataveri | \glt ‘As for Taparahi’s father, his work (lit. the working) was in Mataveri.’

Knowledge Point: Topicalisation tends to happen especially with proper nouns\is{Noun!proper} and pronouns; however, it also occurs with common nouns\is{Noun!common}, as \REF{ex:8.82} above shows. What they all have in common, is that they bring a participant to the front which has been introduced earlier and is known to the hearers.\footnote{\label{fn:424}There are a few interesting exceptions, where topicalisation is used right at the start of a story. The following sentence is an example:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{tū} \textbf{hoi} \textbf{era} i e\ꞌa haka\ꞌou ki ruŋa. \textbf{Ko} \textbf{tū} \textbf{poki} \textbf{era} i hiŋa era ki raro he rerehu rō atu \ꞌai. | \gls PROM DEM horse DIST PFV go_up again to above PROM DEM child DIST PFV fall DIST to below PRED faint EMPH away SUBS | \glt ‘(The horse and the boy fell.) The horse stood up again. The boy who had fallen down fainted.’

Knowledge Point: Now it could be argued that Rapa Nui has two types of clefts with different functions:\footnote{\label{fn:426}\citet[38]{Clark1976} points out that in most Polynesian languages, clauses with a topicalised\is{Topicalisation} ko{}-marked NP are ambiguous: the ko{}-NP can be either predicate (‘it was John who was chopping the yam’) or topic (‘as for John, he was chopping the yam’). Regardless the analysis of topicalised\is{Topicalisation} constructions, it is clear that the two are syntactically distinguished in Rapa Nui.} a focus construction with head noun and a topicalisation construction without head noun. However, there are syntactic reasons not to analyse topicalising constructions as relative clauses\is{Clause!relative}. In relative clauses\is{Clause!relative}, the neutral aspect marker\is{Aspect marker} he\is{he (aspect marker)} is extremely rare (\sectref{sec:11.4.3}), while he is common in topicalisation constructions like \REF{ex:8.81} above.

Tiare has brought the pumpkin seeds to plant.’

Knowledge Point: These constructions mostly have a habitual or continuous sense. They are very similar to the nominalised actor-emphatic construction (\sectref{sec:8.6.3}), which likewise has a preposed subject followed by a nominalised verb with habitual sense. They are also similar to constructions in which ko is followed by a nominalised verb (see (\ref{ex:3.23}–\ref{ex:3.24}) in \sectref{sec:3.2.3.1}).

Knowledge Point: The sentence may state a general fact about a category as a whole as in \REF{ex:8.91}, or refer to a \is{Specific reference}specific entity or group as in \REF{ex:8.92}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{nu\ꞌu} \textbf{pa\ꞌari} \ꞌina e ko aŋa tahaŋa nō i a koe i te aŋa i mana\ꞌu. | \gls PRED people adult NEG IPFV NEG.IPFV do aimlessly just at PROP 2SG ACC ART work PFV think | \glt ‘Grown-ups don’t simply do{\rmfnm} the work they think of (i.e. without preparation).’
Content 2: \gll ...\ꞌe \textbf{he} \textbf{mataroa} repahoa o koro ko ma\ꞌu mai \ꞌā ka rahi atu te pahu peti. | \gls ~~~and PRED sailor friend of Dad PRF carry hither CONT CNTG many away ART can peach | \glt ‘(When she entered there were many people,) and some sailors, friends of Dad, brought many cans of peaches.’

Knowledge Point: What all these examples have in common, is that the he{}-marked subject is singled out from among other entities; in other words, the he-construction serves as topicalisation. This is particularly clear in \REF{ex:8.93}, where the subject he taŋata is contrasted with other actors in the discourse, and in \REF{ex:8.95}, where the two babies introduced in the preceding context are mentioned individually.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{taŋata} he oho he ruku i te ika mo te hora kai. | \gls PRED man NTR go NTR dive ACC ART fish for ART time eat | \glt ‘(The women sat down to cook the food.) The men went diving for fish for lunch.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{matahiapo} i mate, \textbf{he} \textbf{haŋupotu} i ora. | \gls PRED firstborn PFV die PRED lastborn PFV live | \glt ‘(Two boys were born.) The eldest died, the youngest survived.’

Knowledge Point: In fact, clauses with he{}-marked subjects are very similar to clauses with topicalised\is{Topicalisation} ko{}-marked subjects (\sectref{sec:8.6.2.1}). Ko{}-marked topicalisations refer to individuated entities (a single referent or a clearly defined group) which are accessible\is{Accessibility} to the hearer; in other words, the exact referent of the ko{}-marked subject has been introduced in the preceding context. By contrast, the he{}-marked subjects in the examples above are not accessible as individuated entities. Even though the hearer can infer their existence from the context, they have not been mentioned as such. In \REF{ex:8.93}, the context tells about a group of people – men, women and children – who go on an outing; prior to the sentence quoted here, the men have not been mentioned separately. Similarly, in \REF{ex:8.95}, the preceding sentences tell about the birth of two boys; the hearer can infer the existence of an oldest and a youngest boy, but it is only in the sentence quoted here that each boy is singled out. In both cases, the referent of the he{}-marked noun phrase is not accessible\is{Accessibility} as such, as it has only been introduced as undefined part of a larger group. By contrast, subjects topicalised\is{Topicalisation} with ko{}-marking are always accessible as individual referents; for example in \REF{ex:8.81} above, both mother and Tiare play a role in the preceding context.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{taŋata} he oho he ruku i te ika mo te hora kai. | \gls PRED man NTR go NTR dive ACC ART fish for ART time eat | \glt ‘(The women sat down to cook the food.) The men went diving for fish for lunch.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{matahiapo} i mate, \textbf{he} \textbf{haŋupotu} i ora. | \gls PRED firstborn PFV die PRED lastborn PFV live | \glt ‘(Two boys were born.) The eldest died, the youngest survived.’

Tiare has brought the pumpkin seeds to plant.’

Knowledge Point: As these examples show, the Patient either follows or precedes the verb. When it follows the verb as in \REF{ex:8.96}, it is i{}-marked; when it precedes the verb as in \REF{ex:8.97}, it is unmarked. This corresponds to the general pattern of object marking in Rapa Nui (\sectref{sec:8.4.1}), so there are good reasons to consider the Patient as direct object in either position.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{O} \textbf{tō\ꞌona} \textbf{matu\ꞌa} i aŋa i te hare nei mo Puakiva. | \gls of POSS.3SG.O parent PFV make ACC ART house PROX for Puakiva | \glt ‘It was her father who made this house for Puakiva.’
Content 2: \gll ¡\textbf{\ꞌĀ\ꞌau} rō ta\ꞌa moeŋa nei o māua i toke! | \gls ~POSS.2SG.A EMPH POSS.2SG.A mat PROX of 1DU.EXCL PFV steal | \glt ‘It was you who stole that mat of ours!’

Knowledge Point: The imperfective AE refers to an action posterior\is{Posteriority} to the time of reference. Usually this is the future, but as \REF{ex:8.101} shows, this is not necessarily so:
Content 1: \gll Mā\ꞌana e haka nuinui haka\ꞌou i a rāua i te itaraera. | \gls BEN.3SG.A IPFV CAUS big:RED again ACC PROP 3PL ACC ART Israel | \glt ‘He was the one who would make them, the Israelites, great again.’

Knowledge Point: The use of possessives to express arguments in main clauses is largely speaker-depen\-dent: this construction is frequent in some texts, but absent in others. Though the precise conditions are not clear, possessive marking appears to be a device to demote\is{Subject!demotion} a non-salient\is{Salience} Agent. The fact that this is only found with the neutral marker he, which is also the nominal predicate marker, suggests that these clauses have been nominalised: \REF{ex:8.110} could tentatively be paraphrased as ‘(There was) the saying of that old woman...’. In that case, the verb is nominalised and he is the nominal predicate marker.\footnote{\label{fn:432}The directional atu in \REF{ex:8.111} may suggest that the phrase is still a verb phrase, but notice that atu occasionally occurs with nominalised verbs (\sectref{sec:3.2.3.3}).}

Knowledge Point: Generally speaking, ki tends to be used with more intensive or purposeful actions. \textit{\mbox{U{\ꞌ}i} i} and \textit{u{\ꞌ}i ki} both mean ‘to look at, to watch’, but \textit{u{\ꞌ}i ki} may indicate a more focused attention as in \REF{ex:8.113}, or is used in the sense ‘to look for, to search’, as in \REF{ex:8.114}:
Content 1: \gll He u\ꞌi \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{hare} \textbf{era} i kā mai era te \ꞌau o te \ꞌumu. | \gls NTR look to ART house DIST PFV ignite hither DIST ART smoke of ART earth_oven | \glt ‘She looked to the houses where the smoke of the earth oven rose (in order to snatch the food as soon as it was cooked).’
Content 2: \gll He u\ꞌi a roto i te vai \textbf{ki} \textbf{tū} \textbf{ika} \textbf{era}, \ꞌina kai take\ꞌa. | \gls NTR look by inside at ART water to DEM fish DIST NEG NEG.PFV see | \glt ‘He looked for that fish in the water, but did not see it.’

Knowledge Point: Hakaroŋo\is{haka roŋo ‘to listen’} i means ‘to hear’ or ‘to listen’. Hakaroŋo\is{haka roŋo ‘to listen’} ki likewise means ‘to listen’, but is also used in a more intensive sense: ‘to pay attention’ or ‘to obey’, as in \REF{ex:8.116}.
Content 1: \gll A Tiare poki hakaroŋo \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{nua}. | \gls PROP Tiare child listen to PROP Mum | \glt ‘Tiare is a child who listens to Mum.’

Knowledge Point: With \textit{hā{\ꞌ}ū{\ꞌ}ū} ‘help’, the person helped is usually expressed with ki (though i is found as well), while i marks the activity. In \REF{ex:8.125}, both are used together:
Content 1: \gll Ko Tiare i oho i hā\ꞌū\ꞌū \textbf{ki} a nua \textbf{i} tā\ꞌana aŋa. | \gls PROM Tiare PFV go PFV help to PROP Mum ACC POSS.3SG.A work | \glt ‘Tiare went and helped Mum with her work.’

Knowledge Point: Thirdly, in causative\is{Causative} constructions, the causee (the S/A of the root verb) is expressed as direct object (DO). However, when the root verb is transitive\is{Verb!transitive}, its Patient is often expressed as DO, in which case the DO position is not available for the causee; in that case the causee is expressed as an oblique, introduced by ki (\sectref{sec:8.12.3}). In the following example, the verb \textit{mana{\ꞌ}u} (which may take a ki{}-marked object, see \REF{ex:8.121} above) is causativised. The causee ki a koe ‘you’ is expressed with ki, not i, which suggests that the DO position is already occupied by the noun phrase ki tū vānaŋa...
Content 1: \gll He mana\ꞌu \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{hora} \textbf{era} ō\ꞌona e noho era \ꞌi muri i tō\ꞌona nua era. | \gls NTR think to ART time DIST POSS.3SG.O IPFV stay DIST at near at POSS.3SG.O Mum DIST | \glt ‘He thought about the time when he lived with his mother.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes a Patient or Theme is not expressed as direct object, but as an instrument phrase, marked with the instrumental preposition hai. This preposition (\sectref{sec:4.7.9}) is usually not followed by a determiner (\sectref{sec:5.3.2.2}) and marks a non-specific\is{Specific reference!non-specific reference} entity.\footnote{\label{fn:438}The hai{}-marked Patient in \REF{ex:8.131} could be considered a “demoted object”, which would imply that the construction in \REF{ex:8.131} is derived from the one in \REF{ex:8.130}. While this may seem plausible in some cases, in other cases it is not at all clear that the construction with Patient as DO is more basic than the instrumental construction (see the discussion on (\ref{ex:8.136}–\ref{ex:8.139}) below). \citet{Goldberg1995} argues that it is unnecessary and often unwarranted to assume a transformational relationship between two constructions with alternative argument expression.}

Two pairs of examples: \REF{ex:8.130} and \REF{ex:8.132} show the usual construction with the Patient as DO, while in \REF{ex:8.131} and \REF{ex:8.133} the same argument is marked with hai.\footnote{\label{fn:439}Notice that non-specific\is{Specific reference!non-specific reference} objects can also be constructed with a \textsc{acc} marker + determiner; see examples (\ref{ex:5.34}–\ref{ex:5.36}) in section \sectref{sec:5.3.3}.}

Knowledge Point: Argument expression by means of hai is especially common with verbs that involve both a Theme (or Patient) and a Goal (or Recipient or Beneficiary), like \textit{va{\ꞌ}ai} ‘to give’ and hoa ‘to throw’. The Theme of \textit{va{\ꞌ}ai} is usually expressed as DO, while the Goal is marked with ki, as in \REF{ex:8.134}. In \REF{ex:8.135} however, the Goal is expressed as DO, while the Patient ‘food’ is marked with hai. The motivation for this may be pragmatic: the Goal is more topical in discourse, hence expressed as a core argument.\footnote{\label{fn:440}In the terminology of \citealt{Haspelmath2005} (quoted in \citealt{Reesink2013}), the DO-Theme construction is “indirective”, while the hai{}-Theme construction is “secundative”. Reesink finds that in a sample of 72 Papuan languages, a large majority has a secundative construction as the only option. In languages that allow a choice between both constructions, the choice may be determined by a variety of pragmatic factors.}

Content 1: \gll Ku ŋaro\ꞌa \ꞌā te honu te kī \textbf{\ꞌa} \textbf{Ku\ꞌuku\ꞌu}. | \gls PRF perceive CONT ART turtle ART say of.A Ku’uku’u | \glt ‘The turtle heard what Ku’uku’u said (lit. heard the saying of Ku’uku’u).’

Knowledge Point: The Patient usually has the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)}, regardless whether the Agent is expressed or not; cf. \REF{ex:8.163} above and \REF{ex:8.166} below:
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI te kī nō \textbf{o} \textbf{Puakiva} ki a Pea i tā\ꞌana vānaŋa... | \gls at ART say just of Puakiva to PROP Pea ACC POSS.3SG.A word | \glt ‘When Puakiva was still saying (lit. in the saying of Puakiva) his words to Pea...’

Knowledge Point: This also has consequences for content questions\is{Question!content} with the interrogative pronoun ai\is{ai ‘who’} ‘who’. Interrogative subjects and objects are constructed as clefts, nominal clauses\is{Clause!nominal} containing a relative clause\is{Clause!relative} (\sectref{sec:10.3.2.1}–\ref{sec:10.3.2.2}). As a consequence, an interrogative direct object is not marked with the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} i, but as a nominal predicate. By contrast, interrogative obliques are always preceded by the appropriate preposition; this includes recipients, as in \REF{ex:8.172}:
Content 1: \gll ¿\textbf{Ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{ai} \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{ai} i kī ai mo hā\ꞌū\ꞌū mai \ꞌi tō\ꞌona \ꞌati? | \gls ~to PROP who to PROP who PFV say PVP for help hither at POSS.3SG.O problem | \glt ‘Whom and whom did he ask to help him in his problem?’

Content 1: \gll Ko riri rivariva mai \ꞌana a au \textbf{i} \textbf{a} \textbf{koe}. | \gls PRF angry good:RED hither CONT PROP 1SG ACC PROP 2SG | \glt ‘I’m really angry at you.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna koe ko riri \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{nu\ꞌu} \textbf{era}. | \gls NEG 2SG NEG.IPFV angry to ART PL people DIST | \glt ‘Don’t be angry at those people.’

Knowledge Point: Nowadays, ‘about’ tends to be expressed by o ruŋa (see \REF{ex:3.152} on p.~\pageref{ex:3.152}).
Content 1: \gll He \ꞌui\ꞌui nō te aŋa \textbf{o} \textbf{ruŋa} \textbf{i} te \ꞌa\ꞌamu tuai. | \gls PRED ask:RED just ART do of above at ART story ancient | \glt ‘He was always asking about the old stories.’

Knowledge Point: As the examples above show, oblique constituents usually come after the subject. They may also be preposed as in (\ref{ex:8.168}–\ref{ex:8.169}) above. If there is also a direct object, the oblique constituent usually comes last as in \REF{ex:8.173}, though the reverse order also occurs:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ki} a koe a au i oho mai nei. | \gls to PROP 2SG PROP 1SG PFV go hither PROX | \glt ‘To you I have come.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ki} a ia e va\ꞌai era e Tū. | \gls to PROP 3SG IPFV give DIST AG Tu | \glt ‘To him Tu gives it.’
Content 3: \gll He va\ꞌai a nua i te kai \textbf{ki} a koro. | \gls NTR give PROP Mum ACC ART food to PROP Dad | \glt ‘Mum gave the food to Dad.’

Knowledge Point: This happens when the oblique is more topical\is{Topic, topicality} than the direct object, or when the oblique is lighter (i.e. shorter and structurally simpler) than the direct object. In \REF{ex:8.184} the oblique is short, while the direct object is a complex noun phrase.
Content 1: \gll He tuhi e Vaha \obki a Kava\,\cb\textsubscriptOBL~ \obi te kona mo titi o te hare.\,\cb\textsubscriptDO | \gls NTR point_out AG Vaha {\db}to PROP Kava {\db}ACC ART place for stack of ART house | \glt ‘Vaha pointed out to Kava a place to build the house.’

Knowledge Point: Like reflexivity, reciprocality may be expressed by a pronoun + identity marker \textit{{\ꞌ}ā/{\ꞌ}ana} as in \REF{ex:8.189}, or left implicit as in \REF{ex:8.190}\is{a (identity)@{\ꞌ}ā (identity)}:
Content 1: \gll He hēŋu\ꞌiŋu\ꞌi rō atu \ꞌai tū ŋā rū\ꞌau era \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{rāua} \textbf{\ꞌā}. | \gls NTR murmur:RED EMPH away SUBS DEM PL old_woman DIST to PROP 3PL IDENT | \glt ‘Then the old women began to murmur to each other (among themselves).’
Content 2: \gll Te taŋata \ꞌe te vi\ꞌe e ai ena mo hā\ꞌū\ꞌū ki a \textbf{rāua}. | \gls ART person and ART woman IPFV exist MED for help to PROP 3PL | \glt ‘Man and woman are there to help each other.’

Knowledge Point: 1 is specified for number and person, 2 for number. Both 1 and 2 are used in an inclusory\is{Pronoun!inclusory} sense: they denote the total set of referents of NP\textsubscript{1} and NP\textsubscript{2}. In other words, when both NP\textsubscript{1} and NP\textsubscript{2} are singular, the comitative\is{Comitative} marker is dual if a dual form is available (i.e. in the 1\textsuperscript{st} person) and plural otherwise; when either NP\textsubscript{1} or NP\textsubscript{2} is dual or plural, the comitative\is{Comitative} marker is plural. This is illustrated in \REF{ex:8.191} above, where the plural rāua connects two singular noun phrases.
Content 1: \gll He hoki Makemake\textsubscript1 rāua\textsubscriptCOM ~ko Haua\textsubscript2. | \gls NTR return Makemake 3PL ~PROM Haua | \glt ‘Makemake and Haua returned.’

Knowledge Point: First and second person pronouns can also be used as comitative\is{Comitative} markers, and they are inclusory\is{Pronoun!inclusory} as well. First person pronouns make a distinction between dual and plural. Dual pronouns are used when NP\textsubscript{1} and NP\textsubscript{2} are both singular as in \REF{ex:8.194}; when NP\textsubscript{1} and/or NP\textsubscript{2} is plural as in \REF{ex:8.195}, the pronoun is plural.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĪ au he iri \textbf{māua} \textbf{ko} Taria ki te māua ketekete. | \gls IMM 1SG NTR ascend 1DU.EXCL PROM Taria to ART 1DU.EXCL ketekete | \glt ‘I’m going up with Taria to find ketekete (a kind of plant).’
Content 2: \gll He hoki koe \textbf{kōrua} \textbf{ko} te matu\ꞌa ko Iporito Roussel. | \gls NTR return 2SG 2PL PROM ART parent PROM Hippolyte Roussel | \glt ‘(spoken to one man:) You will return with father Hippolyte Roussel.’

Subsection: Ararua and ananake ‘together’ as comitative markers\label{sec:8.10.3
Knowledge Point: Ananake is used for sets larger than two, in which NP\textsubscript{1} and/or NP\textsubscript{2} is plural. In \REF{ex:8.197} NP\textsubscript{1} ‘the people’ is plural, while NP\textsubscript{2} is singular. In \REF{ex:8.198}, NP\textsubscript{1} is singular while NP\textsubscript{2} is plural.
Content 1: \gll He takataka he oho te taŋata \ꞌi rote hare pure ki te hāpī \textbf{ananake} \textbf{ko} te matu\ꞌa. | \gls NTR gather:RED NTR go ART man at inside_ART house prayer to ART learn together PROM ART parent | \glt ‘The people gathered in the church to learn together with the priest.’
Content 2: \gll He noho a Uho \textbf{ananake} \textbf{ko} te matu\ꞌa, ko te taina. | \gls NTR stay PROP Uho together PROM ART parent PROM ART sibling | \glt ‘Uho lived together with her parents and siblings.’

Subsection: Ararua and ananake ‘together’ as comitative markers\label{sec:8.10.3
Knowledge Point: Here are two examples. In these constructions, both the comitative marker (ararua/ananake) and the NP\textsubscript{1} pronoun are inclusory, denoting the total set of referents of NP\textsubscript{1} and NP\textsubscript{2}: plural in \REF{ex:8.199}, dual in \REF{ex:8.200}.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĀhani \ꞌō ananake mātou ko tō\ꞌoku hua\ꞌai era. | \gls if_only really together 1PL.EXCL PROM POSS.1SG.O family DIST | \glt ‘I wish I were together with my family.’
Content 2: \gll Ararua kōrua ko te \ꞌAtua. | \gls the_two 2PL PROM ART God | \glt ‘(the angel said to Mary:) God is with you.’

Subsection: Pronouns as NP\textsubscript{1: inclusory and exclusory use\label{sec:8.10.6
Knowledge Point: \is{Inclusory pronoun}When NP\textsubscript{1} in a comitative\is{Comitative} construction is a pronoun, it may either include or exclude the referent(s) of NP\textsubscript{2}; in other words, it may be either inclusory\is{Pronoun!inclusory} or exclusory.\footnote{\label{fn:448}Other examples are found in the previous sections. Inclusory use of a pronoun as NP\textsubscript{1} is found in (\ref{ex:8.199}–\ref{ex:8.200}) above, exclusory use in (\ref{ex:8.194}–\ref{ex:8.195}). Notice that in the last two examples, an exclusory pronoun as NP\textsubscript{1} is followed by an inclusory pronoun as comitative marker.} In \REF{ex:8.209}, the dual pronoun māua is inclusory\is{Pronoun!inclusory}: its reference includes NP\textsubscript{2} Peŋipeŋi: ‘me and Pengipengi’.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĀhani \ꞌō ananake mātou ko tō\ꞌoku hua\ꞌai era. | \gls if_only really together 1PL.EXCL PROM POSS.1SG.O family DIST | \glt ‘I wish I were together with my family.’
Content 2: \gll Ararua kōrua ko te \ꞌAtua. | \gls the_two 2PL PROM ART God | \glt ‘(the angel said to Mary:) God is with you.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌĪ au he iri \textbf{māua} \textbf{ko} Taria ki te māua ketekete. | \gls IMM 1SG NTR ascend 1DU.EXCL PROM Taria to ART 1DU.EXCL ketekete | \glt ‘I’m going up with Taria to find ketekete (a kind of plant).’
Content 4: \gll He hoki koe \textbf{kōrua} \textbf{ko} te matu\ꞌa ko Iporito Roussel. | \gls NTR return 2SG 2PL PROM ART parent PROM Hippolyte Roussel | \glt ‘(spoken to one man:) You will return with father Hippolyte Roussel.’
Content 5: \gll E tahi mahana \textbf{māua} ararua ko Peŋipeŋi e noho era \ꞌi Tu\ꞌu Tapu. | \gls NUM one day 1DU.EXCL the_two PROM Pengipengi IPFV stay DIST at Tu’u Tapu | \glt ‘One day, Pengipengi and I were staying in Tu’u Tapu.’

Subsection: Pronouns as NP\textsubscript{1: inclusory and exclusory use\label{sec:8.10.6
Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:8.210}, NP\textsubscript{1} is exclusory: the pronoun is singular and does not include NP\textsubscript{2} ‘a person of your house’.
Content 1: \gll ¿\ꞌI \ꞌaŋahē te mahana hope\ꞌa i noho i vānaŋa rivariva \textbf{koe} ararua ko te kope e tahi o tu\ꞌu hare? | \gls ~at when.PAST ART day last PFV sit PFV talk good:RED 2SG the_two PROM ART person NUM one of POSS.2SG.O house | \glt ‘When was the last day you sat down and talked well with a person of your house?’

Knowledge Point: Underlyingly, both NP\textsubscript{1} and the comitative\is{Comitative} marker are an inclusory\is{Pronoun!inclusory} pronoun, and one of these identical pronouns gets deleted. This analysis would explain an otherwise unexplained gap in the list of comitative\is{Comitative} constructions. There are cases where NP\textsubscript{1} is an inclusory\is{Pronoun!inclusory} pronoun and the comitative\is{Comitative} marker is a different inclusory\is{Pronoun!inclusory} form (such as ananake, see (\ref{ex:8.199}–\ref{ex:8.199}) on p.~\pageref{ex:8.199}); there are also cases where NP\textsubscript{1} is a full noun phrase and the comitative\is{Comitative} marker is an inclusory\is{Pronoun!inclusory} pronoun (\sectref{sec:8.10.2}); but there are no cases where both NP\textsubscript{1} and the comitative\is{Comitative} marker are a pronoun. A deletion strategy would explain why the latter do not occur.\footnote{\label{fn:452}The reasons for this deletion could be pragmatic: a repeated pronoun can be perceived as redundant or stylistically awkward.}
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĀhani \ꞌō ananake mātou ko tō\ꞌoku hua\ꞌai era. | \gls if_only really together 1PL.EXCL PROM POSS.1SG.O family DIST | \glt ‘I wish I were together with my family.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌĀhani \ꞌō ananake mātou ko tō\ꞌoku hua\ꞌai era. | \gls if_only really together 1PL.EXCL PROM POSS.1SG.O family DIST | \glt ‘I wish I were together with my family.’

Knowledge Point: Vocative phrases occur in various positions in the sentence: initial as in \REF{ex:8.214}, after the first phrase or clause as in \REF{ex:8.215}, and final as in \REF{ex:8.216}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{Eva,} \textbf{e} \textbf{Eva}, ka \ꞌara koe. | \gls VOC Eva VOC Eva IPFV wake_up 2SG | \glt ‘Eva, Eva, wake up.’
Content 2: \gll ¿He obispo rā, \textbf{e} \textbf{koro} \textbf{ē}, e tu\ꞌura\ꞌarima \ꞌā i te ŋā poki? | \gls ~NTR bishop DIST VOC Dad VOC IPFV confirmation CONT ACC ART PL child | \glt ‘Is that the bishop, uncle, confirming the children?’
Content 3: \gll ¿Ko ŋaro\ꞌa \ꞌana e koe, \textbf{e} \textbf{Hana} \textbf{ē}? | \gls ~PRF perceive CONT AG 2SG VOC Hana VOC | \glt ‘Did you hear that, Hana?’

Knowledge Point: As \REF{ex:8.215} and \REF{ex:8.216} show, the end of a vocative\is{Vocative} phrase is often marked by ē.\footnote{\label{fn:453}This particle is glossed \textsc{voc}, but it may be compared to two other particles ē which occur before a pause: ē in the expression pē nei ē ‘thus’, which occurs before an indirect speech (\sectref{sec:4.6.5.1}), and ē indicating an ongoing event (found e.g. in \REF{ex:7.159} on p.~\pageref{ex:7.159}).} This particle is always used when the vocative\is{Vocative} occurs in the middle or at the end of a clause, but rarely with initial vocatives.
Content 1: \gll ¿He obispo rā, \textbf{e} \textbf{koro} \textbf{ē}, e tu\ꞌura\ꞌarima \ꞌā i te ŋā poki? | \gls ~NTR bishop DIST VOC Dad VOC IPFV confirmation CONT ACC ART PL child | \glt ‘Is that the bishop, uncle, confirming the children?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Ko ŋaro\ꞌa \ꞌana e koe, \textbf{e} \textbf{Hana} \textbf{ē}? | \gls ~PRF perceive CONT AG 2SG VOC Hana VOC | \glt ‘Did you hear that, Hana?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{e\ꞌa} \textbf{nei} te taŋata nei \ꞌi tū ra\ꞌā era he oho mai ē... | \gls PFV go_out PROX ART man PROX at DEM day DIST NTR go hither on_and_on | \glt ‘When this man had gone out that day, he kept going...’

Knowledge Point: Haka is used with intransitive\is{Verb!intransitive} verbs, transitive\is{Verb!transitive} verbs, adjectives and nouns; examples will be given in the following sections. Furthermore, it is used with copula verbs\is{Verb!copula} (see \REF{ex:8.239} below)\footnote{\label{fn:454}According to \citet[251]{Dixon2012}, this is crosslinguistically unusual.} and with adverbs (see \REF{ex:8.249}). There are no examples in the corpus where it is used with locationals\is{Locational}.
Content 1: \gll He haka riro i a ia pa he pīkea. | \gls NTR CAUS become ACC PROP 3SG like PRED crab | \glt ‘She made herself like a crab.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{haka} \textbf{koro\ꞌiti} koe ana vānaŋa mai. | \gls EXH CAUS softly 2SG IRR speak hither | \glt ‘Speak softly (lit. make softly when you speak)!’

Knowledge Point: Regarding the morphological status of haka: in many analyses of Polynesian languages, haka is considered a prefix and written together with the root. Semantic motivations may play a role here: haka + root forms a derived verb with its own argument structure, often with a lexicalised (i.e. non-predictable) meaning. However, phonologically and morphologically haka is no different from preverbal particles. There is no phonological integration with the root: haka does not affect the root phonologically any more than particles do. Moreover, haka may be separated from the root by preverbal particles, both degree modifiers (see \REF{ex:8.250} below) and the constituent negator \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e}:
Content 1: \gll Te tire e haŋa rō \ꞌā mo \textbf{haka} \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{māramarama} i a rāua. | \gls ART Chile IPFV want EMPH IDENT for CAUS more intelligent ACC PROP 3PL | \glt ‘The Chileans want to pass themselves off as smarter.’

Knowledge Point: In many cases haka expresses direct causation, as illustrated by the following pair of examples. In \REF{ex:8.221} the Theme argument ‘the fire’ is the subject; in \REF{ex:8.222}, an (implicit) Agent has been added, expressing the persons causing the fire to burn; the Theme argument is now expressed as direct object.
Content 1: \gll I totomo era ki \ꞌuta, e \textbf{hū} rō \ꞌā te ahi. | \gls PFV PL:go_ashore DIST to inland IPFV burn EMPH IDENT ART fire | \glt ‘When they came ashore, a fire was burning.’
Content 2: \gll He noho he \textbf{haka} \textbf{hū} i te ahi. | \gls NTR sit NTR CAUS burn ACC ART fire | \glt ‘They sat down and lighted (made burn) the fire.’

Knowledge Point: This example involves an inanimate argument and a non-agentive verb. With agentive verbs, the Agent of the root (the causee) is often actively involved in the event, despite the presence of additional Agent (the causer). In \REF{ex:8.224} the children are just as much the Agent of going as in \REF{ex:8.223}, even though another Agent has been added.
Content 1: \gll He \textbf{haka} \textbf{oho} i te ŋā poki ki haho mo kokori. | \gls NTR CAUS go ACC ART PL child to outside for PL:play | \glt ‘She made the children go outside to play.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI te ahiahi he \textbf{oho} te ŋā poki ki Mataveri. | \gls at ART afternoon NTR go ART PL child to Mataveri | \glt ‘In the afternoon, the children went to Mataveri.’

Knowledge Point: Non-agentive verbs – which have a Theme as subject – become agentive by causativisation, as the following pair of examples shows. In \REF{ex:8.226}, the subject koe is Theme, while i marks the Agent (\sectref{sec:8.6.4.7} on non-argument Agents). In \REF{ex:8.227}, the subject koe is Agent, while i marks the direct object.
Content 1: \gll E ko \textbf{rehu} koe i a au. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV forgotten 2SG at PROP 1SG | \glt ‘I won’t forget you (lit. you won’t be forgotten to/by me).’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna koe ko \textbf{haka} \textbf{rehu} i a au. | \gls NEG 2SG NEG.IPFV CAUS forgotten ACC PROP 1SG | \glt ‘Don’t forget me.’

Knowledge Point: When adjectives are causativised, the property expressed by the adjective is brought about by an Agent; the person or thing having the property is expressed as direct object, i te pista in \REF{ex:8.228}, te tātou mahana in \REF{ex:8.229}.
Content 1: \gll Rā pau era mo \textbf{haka} \textbf{roaroa} i te pista mo rāua \ꞌā e aŋa. | \gls DIST cost DIST for CAUS long:RED ACC ART airstrip for 3PL IDENT IPFV do | \glt ‘The cost for lengthening\is{Vowel!lengthening} the airstrip, they will pay it themselves.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna ko \textbf{haka} \textbf{rakerake} te tātou mahana. | \gls NEG NEG.IPFV CAUS bad:RED ART 1PL.INCL day | \glt ‘Don’t spoil our day.’

Knowledge Point: Haka may also express indirect causation (cf. \citealt[274]{Dixon2012}). In this case, the Agent does not actively bring about the event, but facilitates the event in some way. This may involve letting a natural process run its course as in \REF{ex:8.230}, giving permission as in \REF{ex:8.231}, or waiting for something to happen as in \REF{ex:8.232}:
Content 1: \gll He haha\ꞌo ki roto te vai... mo \textbf{haka} \textbf{piro} \textbf{haka} \textbf{kōpiro} \ꞌi roto i te vai. | \gls NTR insert to inside ART water for CAUS rotten CAUS ferment at inside at ART water | \glt ‘He put the fibres in the water to let them rot and ferment in the water.’
Content 2: \gll Ka \textbf{haka} \textbf{noho} nō atu koe i a au \ꞌi nei. | \gls IMP CAUS stay just away 2SG ACC PROP 1SG at PROX | \glt ‘Let me stay here (allow me to stay here).’
Content 3: \gll He noho he \textbf{haka} \textbf{ahiahi}, \ꞌai ka turu ki tai. | \gls NTR stay NTR CAUS afternoon there CNTG go_down to sea | \glt ‘We stay until the (late) afternoon, then we go down to the sea.’

Knowledge Point: All the examples so far involve intransitive\is{Verb!intransitive} predicates; with these predicates, the original subject (the causee) is demoted to direct object (DO), while the causative\is{Causative} Agent occupies the subject position. Now when the root is a transitive\is{Verb!transitive} verb, the DO position is already occupied.\footnote{\label{fn:455}Languages employ various strategies in this case; \citet[256 263]{Dixon2012} lists five.} In that case, the original direct object remains the direct object; the causee is expressed as oblique\is{Oblique}, marked with the preposition ki. This happens whether the DO is expressed as in (\ref{ex:8.233}–\ref{ex:8.234}),\footnote{\label{fn:456}In \REF{ex:8.233} the object is preverbal, therefore it does not have the \textsc{acc} marker (\sectref{sec:8.4.1}).} or implied as in \REF{ex:8.235}.
Content 1: \gll Ta\ꞌato\ꞌa me\ꞌe rakerake e haka aŋa era \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{Puakiva}. | \gls all thing bad:RED IPFV CAUS do DIST to PROP Puakiva | \glt ‘He made Puakiva do all bad jobs.’
Content 2: \gll He haka tike\ꞌa \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{Tuhi} \textbf{Ira} i tō\ꞌona kahu huruhuru. | \gls NTR CAUS see to PROP Tuhi Ira ACC POSS.3SG.O clothes feather | \glt ‘He showed (=caused to see) Tuhi Ira his feather coat.’
Content 3: \gll Ta\ꞌato\ꞌa me\ꞌe rakerake e haka aŋa era \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{Puakiva}. | \gls all thing bad:RED IPFV CAUS do DIST to PROP Puakiva | \glt ‘He made Puakiva do all bad jobs.’
Content 4: \gll He to\ꞌo mai te matu\ꞌa i te raŋo... He haka \ꞌamo \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{taŋata}. | \gls NTR take hither ART parent ACC ART support NTR CAUS carry to ART man | \glt ‘The father took the stretcher... He made the men carry (it).’

Knowledge Point: The same happens when the root is a middle verb which takes a direct object introduced by ki; see the discussion about \REF{ex:8.129} in \sectref{sec:8.6.4.2}.
Content 1: \gll ...mo haka mana\ꞌu atu \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{koe} ki tū vānaŋa kī mai era e koe ki a au. | \gls ~~~for CAUS think away to PROP 2SG to DEM word say hither DIST AG 2SG to PROP 1SG | \glt ‘(We came) to remind you of the words you said to me.’

Knowledge Point: Causatives of intransitive\is{Verb!intransitive} predicates may be used reflexively: the causee is a pronoun which is coreferential with the Agent. The causative\is{Causative} verb haka paka (lit. ‘cause to be conspicuous’) means ‘to honour, praise’; in \REF{ex:8.238} it is used reflexively in the sense ‘to praise oneself, to brag’, and the object i a ia is coreferential to the implied subject.
Content 1: \gll Ku mate atu \ꞌā a au \ꞌi te kata \ꞌi tū haka paka era i a ia. | \gls PRF die away CONT PROP 1SG at ART laugh at DEM CAUS conspicuous DIST ACC PROP 3SG | \glt ‘I laughed my head off from his bragging.’

Knowledge Point: The same phenomenon can be observed with adjectives. While haka + adjective may be a true causative\is{Causative}, expressing that the property is brought about by an external Agent (see (\ref{ex:8.228}–\ref{ex:8.229}) above), it may also express that the subject reaches a state or acquires a property through intentional action. A few examples:
Content 1: \gll Rā pau era mo \textbf{haka} \textbf{roaroa} i te pista mo rāua \ꞌā e aŋa. | \gls DIST cost DIST for CAUS long:RED ACC ART airstrip for 3PL IDENT IPFV do | \glt ‘The cost for lengthening\is{Vowel!lengthening} the airstrip, they will pay it themselves.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna ko \textbf{haka} \textbf{rakerake} te tātou mahana. | \gls NEG NEG.IPFV CAUS bad:RED ART 1PL.INCL day | \glt ‘Don’t spoil our day.’

Knowledge Point: Haka + adjective or adverb\is{Adverb} may also indicate that the subject acts in a way characterised by the root. As \REF{ex:8.250} shows, this may involve simulating a certain characteristic.\footnote{\label{fn:457}Cf. \citet[14]{Moyle2011} about “similative use” of the causative prefix in \ili{Takuu}.}
Content 1: \gll Te tire e haŋa rō \ꞌā mo \textbf{haka} \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{māramarama} i a rāua. | \gls ART Chile IPFV want EMPH IDENT for CAUS more intelligent ACC PROP 3PL | \glt ‘The Chileans want to pass themselves off as smarter.’

Knowledge Point: Another example is found in \REF{ex:8.248} above: haka honu ‘bodysurfing’ is a lexicalised causative\is{Causative} from honu ‘turtle’. The same sentence also contains the verb hakatiu ‘to watch’; even though this is formally a causative, there is no word tiu in the Rapa Nui lexicon. There are a few more haka forms for which the root as such is not a Rapa Nui word. This includes two very common words: \textit{\mbox{haka{\ꞌ}ou}} ‘again’, hakarē ‘to leave (abandon; permit)’.
Content 1: \gll Ko haka_tiu \ꞌā te repa mai \ꞌuta ki te vaikava mo \textbf{haka} \textbf{aŋiaŋi} ana ai ko tano \ꞌā mo hakahonu. | \gls PRF watch CONT ART young_man from inland to ART sea for CAUS certain:RED IRR exist PRF correct CONT for bodysurf | \glt ‘The young men observe the sea to make sure whether the conditions are fit for surfing.’

Knowledge Point: Other relationships to the noun are possible, whether conventional or creative. In \REF{ex:8.253} the noun refers to something used in the action, or something characterising the direct object as a result of the action. In \REF{ex:8.254} the noun is used in a figurative way (cf. \ili{English} ‘cheeky’).
Content 1: \gll E \textbf{haka} \textbf{tiare} rō \ꞌana i a rāua. | \gls IPFV CAUS flower EMPH CONT ACC PROP 3PL | \glt ‘They have adorned themselves with flowers.’
